title: annegret kramp karrenbauer irish backstop
story: Unlikely because it does not yet exist and requires a sharp change of attitude on all sides.But in times of crisis, ­anything is possible.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are now prepared to vote for ­Theresa May’s shattered EU Withdrawal Bill — as long as she ditches the wretched Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile, Germany is under siege from its political and industrial leaders, who are finally speaking out against a breach in trade and security ties with a vital European ally.Together this makes it ­possible to navigate a way through the thicket of bitterness and rancour which has soured ­politics, ided families and split the British nation.It requires a change of tack from Theresa May — never an easy ask.The PM’s deal is toxic because it hands Northern ­Ireland to Brussels as a ­province of the EU.Cutting out this tumour would win Mrs May the backing of at least  MPs, including Tory Brexiteers and the hardline DUP.Remainers would have ­little choice but to join in, giving Mrs May her majority and scuppering Jeremy ­Corbyn’s demands for a snap election.This might be seen as an impossible dream, not least because the hated backstop was allegedly invented in Downing Street, not Brussels.German negotiators pounced on an easy win.Now Berlin, the ultimate EU power broker, is facing fierce protests from industrialists over the risk to car, aerospace and engineering giantsBritain leaves with No Deal.“A hard Brexit would be disastrous,” says Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s BDI — the equivalent of our Confederation of British Industry.“It would cause great dficulty for tens of thousands of companies and hundreds of thousands of workers on both sides.”Friday’s touching note from German politicians to The Times newspaper pleads with Britain to stay — or at least leave on friendly terms.But this is no love letter. It is hard-nosed realism.Signicantly, it bears the ­signature of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Angela Merkel’s chosen successor as Germany’s next Chancellor.Her appeal can be seen as a rebuke to Mrs Merkel, who rejected David Cameron’s plea for help to curb immigration, tipping ­Britain towards Brexit.Brits might have chosen dferentlyshe had responded to voters’ dismay not just in Britain but across the EU.She later signed her own political death warrant by flinging open Europe’s borders to a million Syrian migrants.But voters’ resentment towards arrogant EU leaders — recorded by their own Eurostat polling system — long predates immigration.Embattled French President Emmanuel Macron recently admitted he had dared not offer his voters a “Frexit”  ­referendum — because they would leave in a flash.Weeks later, his fears were confirmed as “yellow-vest” anarchists set Paris ablaze.French observers believe the gilets jaunes riots have their origins in another referendum crisis.In , France voted overwhelmingly against the European Constitution — only to see it renamed the Lisbon Treaty and slyly introduced against their express wishes.The European Constitution, like the disastrous euro, was a crucial but unpopular step towards a federal European superstate.Ireland and ­Denmark have also voted down EU moves to ever-closer union.They were told to vote again until they said Yes.Brussels’ arrogant contempt for ordinary voters — dismissed by one French president as “scum” — is what politicians blithely describe as the “democratic deficit”.It sowed the seeds for Brexit. Immigration simply brought it to a head.Germany’s letter to The Times reads like a plea from a deserted lover.“Without your great nation, this continent would not be what it is today — a community defined by freedom and ­prosperity,” writes Germany’s next Chancellor.“Should Britain wish to leave the European Union for good, it will always have friends in Germany and Europe.”This is precisely what British voters hoped for as they ­teetered on the brink of Remain but opted to Leave.They wanted a civilised orce between economic and diplomatic allies.This is still possiblethe border issue can be resolved.If we can persuade the IRA to decommission deadly weapons, surely we can decommission a backstop that nobody wants Theresa May’s rejected deal is not a total failure. Without this problem it could still fly.Germany holds the key.If Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer means what she said about friendship, now is the time to prove it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the shocking ways people have tried to treat stis
story: And the historical ways of treating them are arguably worse, with infected people being subjected to hot irons to their bits and being forced to bathe in blood-sucking leeches.While STIs are often treated with medication as they are caused by bacteria and viruses passed on during sex, UK experts have expressed concern about new super-strains of the conditions that are resistant to all treatments.And without antibiotics - or when they dont work - people in the past have resorted to more extreme methods of getting rid of gruesome STIs, such as having lethal mercury rubbed on them and even having sex with virgins...Between the s and , French doctors were convinced they had found the best way of getting rid of the oozing pus in the genital area caused by gonorrhoea.Sufferers were smacked with hard books to try and coax the yellow goop out of their rectum.The ancient Romans believed the only way to get rid of genital herpes was to directly burn the infected flesh with a hot iron.A Greek doctor, Solanus of Ephesus, suggested that gonorrhoea was caused by a build-up of semen in the body, and prescribed lead weights strapped to the body for recovery.Just across the Mediterranean in Egypt, sufferers lay in agony while spells to drive away the demons they thought caused the illness were read out.They also used ointments made from herbs and garlic in an attempt to ease the pain.The ancient Egyptians cast spells and applied ointments made with garlic to genitaliaWhile we now know its highly-toxic to humans, mercury was used for centuries as a way to treat syphilis.This dangerous method cropped up as recently as the early s in Europe.An Italian doctor, Roger of Salerno, made two rather horric suggestions for STI treatments in the s.He recommended people should be bathed in a pool of blood-sucking leeches which he thought could slowly remove traces of the disease from the veins.His other option was urethral irrigation which would have involved a - probably unsterilised - object used to wash out the problem.Elsewhere in medieval Europe, doctors recommended patients be covered in sweating cloths first dipped in a liquid containing dangerous lead.Then, during the Renaissance, between  and , there was a widespread belief that having sex with a female virgin could treat you.Known as the virgin cure, men were wrongly convinced the purity of the woman would absolve them of the disease.In Italy in the s, it was thought sleeping with African women was the perfect antidote.By the s, as many as one in three diseased soldiers and sailors had an STI, and many Victorians were convinced the problem lay with prostitutes.The government passed laws allowing police to arrest, examine, detain, and treat women who they believed were selling sex.If found to be infected, these women were kept in a lock house - a hospital or workhouse - to sit out their symptoms, or thrown in jail for up to a year.Poor people with STIs were refused treatment at charitable hospitals, and were left dependent on donations and benefactors, as society still felt venereal diseases were a punishment for past vice.The upper classes in the nineteenth century still didnt have great solutions, though, and some were more than their le was worth.This included fumigation, where the sufferer was exposed to - now known to be toxic - vapours fused with mercury or silver nitrate.Doctors would often apply too high a dose and accidentally kill their patients.It was several decades before penicillin came on the scene in  as an effective cure for early syphilis.However, attitudes that STIs were the fault of women - and not men - prevailed, and in the same year images at army bases showed the mugshots of women who had tested positive displayed on a board.It was another century before antibiotics and antiviral drugs were introduced to blitz STIs - but with them on the increase in the UK we could soon have to look to other options to banish the bugs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsAirbus says the government asked them to make clear the impact of no deal BrexitIt was revealed after the chief executive branded the Tories handling of Brexit as "disgraceful" before threatening to move the company out of the UKShareByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video airbus-ceo-urges-uk-decision-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAirbus have admitted the government asked the company to make clear the potential impact of no deal on its business.It was revealed after the chief executive branded the Tories handling of Brexit as disgraceful before threatening to move the company out of the UK.The senior vice president of the Katherine Bennett indicated that the Government asked the company to make clear the potential impact of a no-deal scenario. Askedthe Government had put the firm up to issue warnings about the consequences of leaving the EU without an agreement, Ms Bennett told Sky News: No, the Government didnt. The Government have been talking to us and other industry representatives all the time, of course, and weve given them lots of information about the potential impacts.   But they did say could you make sure that you make clear the potential impact of a no deal , and we are happy to do that because no deal is potentially going to be catastrophic for us. Chief executive Tom Enders issued a naked threat to leave the UK by warning it was madness to assume the firm will stay. He said: If theres a no-deal Brexit, we at Airbus will have to make potentially very harmful decisions for the UK. Business Minister Richard Harrington welcomed the companys threat in a frank admission. He said: This is a disaster for business. I am very happy to be public about it and very happythe prime minister decides I am not the right person [to be business minister as a result.]  Mr Enders video message in the latest business blow to Britain Britain as the March  date to leave ticks closer. In recent days Dyson has announced its head office will move to Singapore and PO Ferries re-flagged its whole fleet to Cyprus. Airbus employs more than , people in the UK with around , more jobs connected in supply chains.   In a global economy the UK no longer has the capability to go it alone. Major aerospace projects are multinational affairs, Mr Enders said in his video message. It is a disgrace that, more than two years after the result of the  referendum, businesses are still unable to plan properly for the future. We, along with many of our peers, have repeatedly called for clarity, but we still have no idea what is really going on here.It is not the first time Airbus has threatened to pull out of the UK over Brexit. Last year the firm said it would reconsider its investments in the UK, and its long-term footprint in the countrythere is no deal.Theresa May has repeatedly refused calls to take the threat of a No Deal Brexit off the table.But MPs are set to approve a move next week that could delay Brexit and stop a No Deal being triggered on March .No is against the amendment by Labour MP Yvette Cooper but Remain-backing ministers secretly hope it will pass.Chancellor Philip Hammond will the World Economic Forum in Davos that post-Brexit Britain will still be a great place to do business. However, Mr Enders said Britains multibillion-pound aerospace sector, a world-leader for a century, is standing at a precipice. Brexit is threatening to destroy a century of development based on education, research and human capital, he said. If theres a no-deal Brexit, we at Airbus will have to make potentially very harmful decisions for the UK.  Airbuss UK operations generate around pound billion of turnover annually, making it the countrys largest aerospace company. At its  sites it builds components for a broad spectrum of products from planes to helicopters and satellites. Please dont listen to the Brexiteers madness which asserts that because we have huge plants here we will not move and we will always be here. They are wrong, Mr Enders said.   Of course it is not possible to pick up and move our large UK factories to other parts of the world immediately. However, aerospace is a long-term business and we could be forced to redirect future investments in the event of a no-deal Brexit. And, make no mistake, there are plenty of countries out there who would love to build the wings for Airbus aircraft. Theresa Mays spokesman insisted the “UK is an excellent place to do business”. He said: Airbus said in their statement that the delivery of a pragmatic withdrawal agreement that allows for an orderly Brexit is best for Britain. That is exactly why the Prime Minister has been working so hard to deliver a deal that gives businesses certainty, with an implementation period and an orderly exit. He added: “There is no question that leaving a deal is in the best interests of the UK. “Thats why the PM is working hard to achieve that.”

title: brexit whsmith stockpiles six months
story: NewsBrexit: WHSmith stockpiles six months of pens and notebooksThe stationers, who source most of their products from Asia, normally hold between three and four months worth of pens and notepadsShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsWHSmith want to avoid disruptions to the supply of stationery "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email WHSmith have said they are stockpiling six months worth of pens to guard against chaos at the border caused by Brexit .The stationers, who source most of their products from Asia, normally hold between three and four months worth of pens, diaries and notepads. But the boss of the British firm confirmed they were planning to hold six months worth to avoid disruptions to their supplies. Stephen Clarke, WHSmith’s chief executive, told Bloomberg: We’re used to holding quite a bit of forward cover in terms of stock anyway, so what we’ve done is topped that up a little bit to put ourselves in an even better position should there be congestion at ports. It is one of many firms making preparations ahead of the UKs exit on March .  High end clothing firm Joules is setting up a third-party warehouse on the continent which will serve wholesale customers in the EU. It has also arranged for early delivery of its spring-summer collection and increased its foreign currency holdings to protect it from a potentially volatile poind. While luxury fashion house Burberry warned that a no-deal Brexit would be ‘complex’ and could cost the firm tens of millions of pounds in added expenses. Julie Brown, finance chief at the FTSE  company said that crashing out of the EU without a deal ‘would be complex to manage’. In a trading update to the City yesterday she added: The biggest concern is the disruption to the supply chain.

story: NewsBrexit: Why you might have to renew your passport  MONTHS earlyFor most people, the advice is to renew your passport six months before it expires. Butyour passport was valid for more than  years, the rules are very dferentShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN NewsFor most people, the advice is to renew your passport six months before it expires "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSome Brits will have to renew their passports  MONTHS earlythere is a No Deal Brexit. The government has revealed a little-known loophole that could bar families from holiday hotspots like France and Spain this summer. Since last year, Brits have been warned to have at least six months left on their passportthey want to travel to the EU in a No-Deal. But now officials admit some people will need to renew much earlier than that. Its because between  and September , some UK passports were issued with more than  years lespan. Yet those extra months - awarded when people carried over time from their old passport - wont countyou are entering the EU.  Soyou have a passport that is valid for longer than  years, you should not just count six months back from the expiry date to find out when it wont be valid. Instead you should count  years and six months forward from the date it was issued to find out when itll no longer be valid in the EU. Before the scheme ended in , Brits were able to get up to nine months added to the usual -year lespan of their passport.That means, as a maximum, some people will have to renew their passports  months early - nine months that dont count in the EU, plus another six months before the expiry date. Government guidance explains: Since , some adult British passports were issued with a validity longer than  years.If you renewed your passport before it expired, you were allowed to have the time left on your old passport added to your new passport.The maximum validity period possible was  years and  months.  This means you can’t use the expiry date to checkyour adult passport will be valid under the new rules. These rules will only applyBritain leaves the EU on March  without a Brexit deal. That is looking less likely as MPs plot to delay the date of Brexit. But the fact remains that, with just  days to go, the UK has still not agreed any final Brexit deal with the EU. So as it stands, these rules would kick in at pm on Friday  March. Read our full guide to when you should renew your passport here.

story: NewsCheryl Cole superfan spends £, turning home into shrine to pop starShaun Smith, , has covered his Essex home with pictures of the ex-Girls Aloud starShareByLottie ONeill:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video shaun-smith-shows-extensive-cheryl-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Cheryl superfan has spent thousands of pounds turning his home into a shrine to the pop star - after switching from his devotion to Eastenders Ben Mitchelll. Shaun Smiths Essex flat is covered in pictures of the ex-Girls Aloud singer after a pound, makeover. He shelled out the cash on pictures, canvases, ceiling decorations and even a lesize cardboard cut-out of the celeb - best known as Cheryl Cole. Shaun, , told Essex Live: I have a big cardboard cut-out of her and its on my cupboard door as I dont have enough space because I have so much stuff in my front room. I have Cheryl Cole carpet which I had made, I have got three rugs and I even have a dog bed.  I spend so much - I love her. I watched a video on YouTube from Girls Aloudand I was told one of the members was Cheryl Cole and I didnt believe them. But I got the video of Fight For This Love up and I realised it was her, explained the fanatic.   She is a lovely person, shes caring, shes good and has a good voice and personality. She is not rude and appreciates what people do. Also, it doesnt bother her what people say and that is what I like about her. Shaun began his collection seven months ago in the summer of , and has decorated his home top to bottom.  When he looks at his ornaments and custom designs it makes him happy. He said: I feel happy that she is here and I feel content in my le. I feel I have got someone. She is someone I could look up to as a role model. He also claims that the star liked a photo of his collection when she was tagged on Twitter. The superfan has only become fixated on the star, when another actor and character he liked fell off his radar. Shaun previously spent years collecting photos and items with the face of Eastenders Ben Mitchell, played by Harry Reid, between  and .  He had hundreds of pictures of the star in his home, including clothing and cushion covers made to decorate his home. He spent around pound, to cover his flat in his favourite character that he says helped him come out proudly about his sexuality. I have more stuff of Cheryl than I ever had of Harry and Im really happy with having Cheryl, I have picture frames, photos and Im made up and really happy. Shaun fell out of love of the actor and character and admitted he stopped watching the soap. However, he did manage to see one of the last episodes Harry Reid played hardman Phil Mitchells son, in the scene where he flees on a boat.  It has since been announced that the character will be making a comeback to the show with another face and the sixth actor to attempt the role, Max Bowden. Shaun revealed what he thought about the new Ben: I will be very intrigued what the new Ben will be like and how the new guy will play him - I still like the character of Ben Mitchell. But what happened to all of his collectibles  I sold some of my Ben Mitchell stuff and the rest I gave to charity shops, he said.  I have still got my two cardboard cutouts in plastic bags in the shed, as the charity shop said they couldnt take them as they were too big. One of my friends also bought a lot of things from me, such as a laptop case and a lighter. Shaun also became a local star when his Ben Mitchell collection was featured in the press, but he also received unwanted and hurtful comments about his clothing and collection back in . The -year-old was also the victim of theft at kne-point after someone stole pound cash, a mobile phone and a hard drive. The shocking incident occurred on March ,  and left the Basildon nativedevastated as the hard drive held irreplaceable photos of his late mother. Online trolls hit out at Shaun and left hurtful comments about him on social media.  After Shaun became famous locally, people even stopped him to ask for his autograph. Now his attentions are focused on Cheryl, and he says she is here to stay. Thinking about how others react to his obsession, Shaun carries on confidently. Some people said I have gone over the top on Cheryl, he explained, But it has nothing to do with them - its up to me.

title: experts reveal foods most likely
story: NewsExperts reveal the foods that are most likely to ruin your dietChocolate, pizza and biscuits most likely to make you fall off the healthy eating wagonShareCommentsByRob Knight:,  JAN NewsPeople typically make healthy choices on Tuesday but succumb to snacks on Saturday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIce cream, chocolate and pizza are among the treats most likely to make British fitness fanatics fall off the wagon, according to a study. Researchers who polled , gym-goers identied the foods which cause us to stray from our healthy lestyles – including chips, doughnuts and burgers. We’re also tempted to put the dumbbells to one side when faced with the likes of cake, bread and Chinese takeaways. Commissioned by supermarket Iceland, stockists of low-calorie ice cream, Halo Top, the research also found two thirds consider going without their favourite foods to be one of the hardest things about being healthy.   A spokesman for Iceland said: “As the research shows, being fit and healthy doesn’t mean the hankerings for bad foods go away. “So it’s completely understandable we will waiver from time to time. “And it’s typical the foods we most long for tend to be high calorie - however there are foods available which are low calorie and can fill that void.” It also emerged Saturday is the day gym-goers find it hardest to stick to a sensible diet - and they’ll typically succumb to temptation at precisely .pm.   But Tuesday is the day willpower is at its strongest and when those polled are most likely to resist indulgent foods. Wine, beer and fizzy drinks also commonly cause those polled to fall off the healthy wagon - along with crisps, biscuits and sweets. So in order to work off their food sins gym-goers believe they need to exercise a minimum of six times a month. After indulging,  per cent will go out for a long walk, a fth will go swimming and a quarter will go for a run in order to burn off the excess calories.   But four in  revealed the urge for ice cream and other treats is so strong they exercise just so they can eat whatever they want without fear for their waistlines. However, the Iceland research carried out through OnePoll also found half would rather eat the frozen dessert than do a set of squats, lt weights or use a running machine. The spokesman for Iceland added: “Halo Top is the best ice cream on the market right now, there is no compromise on taste or quality so it really is a dessert you can feel good about.”  Top  foods we miss most when working out. story: NewsInside car where toddler Alfie Lamb was crushed to death by mums boyfriendStephen Waterson is accused of deliberately ramming his electric seat onto the three-year-old after he was placed in the back footwell of an Audi A convertibleShareByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsAlfie Lamb died from a cardiac arrest at his home on February  last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the interior of a car where toddler Alfie Lamb was allegedly crushed to death by his mums boyfriend. Stephen Waterson is accused of deliberately ramming his electric seat onto the three-year-old after he was placed in the back footwell of an Audi A convertible by his mum, Adrian Hoare. Alfie died three days later after suffering a cardiac arrest at home in Croydon, south London. Both Waterson, , and Hoare, , deny charges of manslaughter at the Old Bailey. Jurors have been shown the Audi A after it was brought to a court car park as evidence. They were instructed to remain silent as they inspected the car and made notes, while an officer carried out a brief demonstration.  Mr Justice Kerr, presiding over the case, told the  jurors: The purpose of the exercise is for you to see the car. It is not a reconstruction of any kind of what happened. The jurors then took turns peering into the car, inspecting the passenger sear and back footwell. Prosecutor Duncan Atkinson QC claimed the reclined seat was a deliberate action by Waterson, who was angered by the noise and fuss that a three-and-a-half-year-old was making during the journey.Emilie Williams, , was sitting next to Alfies mum Hoare in the back of the car during the ill-fated trip back from shopping in Sutton, south London, on February  last year.  In a videoed police interview, Miss Williams said they all went together, with Marcus Lamb, , driving.She said she was forced to put a second youngster in the rear footwell next to Alfie because she was not allowed to take the childrens car seat. Miss Williams said Alfie was crying so much it sounded like he was choking, but that his mother said he was OK. Marcuss chair was right forward and Stephens chair was right back, she said. Alfie was kicking the chair, asking him to move it forward.  Waterson said no because he said he had to stretch his legs right out, Miss Williams said. Prosecuting, Mr Atkinson said: Until he got into that vehicle with his mother and those others, CCTV showed that Alfie had been fit and well. It follows that during that car journey something happened to Alfie to compress his chest and abdomen so that he went from an active toddler, to a very seriously ill and brain damaged one. The trial continues.

title: man cerebral palsy crawls home
story: NewsMan with cerebral palsy crawls from home as mum appeals for ramp to be installedPartially-sighted Kenneth Murphy also struggles down two concrete steps from the home in South Lanarkshire, ScotlandShareByKelly-Ann Mills:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video heartbreaking-video-shows-agony-cerebral-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA partially-sighted man with cerebral palsy must dangerously crawl out of his house because he has no wheelchair ramp. Kenneth Murphy, , has to bravely inch out his front door before struggling down two concrete steps and getting in his chair. His mum Angela released heartbreaking footage of his daily struggle at the home in South Lanarkshire, Scotland, in a desperate plea for help. She said: “I posted the video as I had simply had enough of the situation and hoped that the video would show the true reality of what Kenneth faces on a day-to-day basis. “He is also partially sighted, so this makes it all the worse for him.   She added: “What makes this harder is that I believe that there is a suitable adapted house available in Larkhall lying empty, yet Kenneth has to live like this. “I have been offered alternatives but they don’t meet his needs.” Angela had been living in an adapted home in Hamilton, but following a family bereavement, moved back to Larkhall. She wanted to be close to her family but the move meant that she was forced to rent. Since then, she said there has been no suitable alternative accommodation for herself and -year-old Kenneth. Angela is reluctant to enter into a long-term tenancy as she hopes to be offered something more practical. But Angela says that the council won’t fit a ramp which would help Kenneth get in and out of the house.   Angela, who posted the clip last Friday, said she has been amazed and touched at the level of interest and support it has gathered. She added: I have been completely overwhelmed by the support that I have received from everyone who has shared and viewed it. I was not expecting anything like this and I am so grateful for everyone’s support.” Larkhall Councillor Richard Nelson claimed he was stunned by the clip. He said: “I was shocked at the footage and immediately contacted Angela to discuss further her situation. “I come from a nursing background and was immediately shocked as I have never seen anything like this before. “I was taken aback with the limited input they have received from both social work and housing. “This is a joint partnership and they are not meeting the needs of Kenny. “No-one in this day and age should have to live like this, in my opinion. “I have now written to both the heads of social work and housing and the chief executive and they have acknowledged that I have written to them all and I am currently awaiting an update.”   Lanark and Hamilton East MP Angela Crawley was also shocked and got involved in Kenneth’s case. She said: “The situation is clearly unacceptable and the council must do more to support Kenneth. “I have written to the local authority and asked them to provide urgent assistance to the family.” A South Lanarkshire Council spokesman said: “All service users are assessed based on their inidual needs and, while it would not be appropriate to go into the details of inidual cases, South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Partnership is committed to supporting this inidual and we are in ongoing discussions with him and his family with regards to his long-term needs. “The council is aware of Mr Murphy’s current housing application and provided advice to the family in December regarding progressing a re-assessment of their current medical priority points to improve their housing prospects. The local team have now made contact with Mr Murphy and his family again to arrange to meet with them this week to continue to provide any support and assistance in this matter.”

title: mum drops nine stone 14
story: NewsMum drops  stone and  dress sizes thanks to diet of microwave ready mealsKelley Robinson controlled her weight by consuming ready meals that contained between  and  caloriesShareCommentsByNeil ShawTfany Lo:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsShe started eating ready meals, which were typically between  and  calories a meal "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has revealed her secret to successfully losing  stone - by eating READY MEALS. Kelley Robinson, , put on eight stone - weighing st at a size  - after giving birth to her son Kylo. She began to feel her knees buckling under the pressure of her enormous frame and even started taking diet pills. But she found that combined with working out, she could actually control her calorie intake much more effectively with the microwave meals. She now weighs a healthy st for her ft frame and is a comfy dress size , Cornwall Live reports.  Her chest and cup size also slimmed down - from a F to a more proportionate E. Kelley said: The ready meals made it so easy for me to keep track of exactly what I was consuming calorie wise. They were quick and easy too. It may not sound healthy but I chose low cal ones and it really helped me get started on my weight loss journey. It has got to the point now where people dont actually recognise me on the street. An old friend of mine did a double take the other day when I said hi as she didnt notice it was me at all. My whole outlook on le is dferent. Before all I did was sit about on the sofa and order takeaways whereas now Im super active and have tonnes of energy all the time.  Kelleywas a size  before having Kylo, now three, but after he was born she developed unhealthy eating habits. She typically had white toast for breakfast, followed by sandwich and crisps for lunch, a takeaway for dinner, while snacking on more crisps, fizzy drinks and chocolate. She piled on eight stone, but soon got fed up, and when she got desperate she tried diet pills. They were dreadful, I had no energy and couldnt stop pooing the whole time, she admitted. It was around this time that her fitness fanatic fianceacute, Ryan Lake, stepped in to help. She said: Ryan was amazing, he could see how depressed I was and just gently took control but by coaxing me to the gym. Id never have had the confidence to do it without him. At first I found it so hard, I wanted to give up, I really hated it but I kept at it and with the changes in my diet too I found that I was actually losing weight! She also started eating ready meals, which were typically between  and  calories a meal. Her favourites were Morrison’s Chicken Tikka Masala, Beef Hot Pots or Macaroni, and she started eating Weetabix and fruit for breakfast, with wraps for lunch. The new mum stopped snacking between meals and started swapping sweet drinks for water.  In the first three months of her new regime she lost a whopping three stone. Kelleysaid: It was after that when I got really strict with myself because I realised that I actually I could do it. I cut out carbs, dairy and even quit the ready meals eventually. In a year Kelley had lost NINE stone. She admitted: Im such a gym bunny now its unreal I go whenever I have a second and absolutely love it. I even get up super early before the kids wake up to go and workout for an hour. I go at least six times a week and make sure to do a mix of cardio and weights. Doing the weights have meant that the saggy skin has really toned up, which is one thing I was worried about losing quite so much. Dedicated Kelley, who is also mother to -year-old Tamzin, has noticed far more than just weight loss benefits from her new regime. Her knees are no longer a problem and her down days are well behind her. The mum-of-two said: I was quite low before as I felt so under-confident but these days I really do feel like a new person. One thing I know is that I couldnt have done it without the support of my amazing family, especially Ryan, who loved me whatever size I was but always wanted the best for me.

title: mum left permanent scars after
story: NewsMum left with permanent scars after neighbour from hell beat her in front of kidsWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES Tony Lloyd, , admitted attacking terried mum-of-two Laura Bonney, , outside her home in CornwallShareByChris Matthews:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTony Lloyd, who pleaded guilty, leaving Truro Crown Court "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman was left with permanent scars after being punched and spat at by her neighbour in front of her children, a court heard. Terried mum-of-two Laura Bonney, , was injured after a long-running feud turned violent outside her home. Tony Lloyd, , admitted carrying out the broad daylight attack. The court heard she needed four stitches and will suffer permanent scarring as a result being punched and spat at by the defendant. Relations between Lloyd, Laura and her husband Daniel Bonney boiled over on June  last year, a judge was told.   Prosecuting, Philip Lee said there had been a background of bad feeling between the parties and the violence was sparked by comments said to have been made by Lloyd to the Bonneys young son. Mr Lee said: The argument escalated and the defendant approached Laura Bonney shouting abuse. They came close and the defendant was calling Laura Bonney trying to goad Mr Bonney. The defendant told police that Laura Bonney kicked him in the groin causing him to stumble back.   The defendant then struck Laura Bonney with a hard punch to the side of the face and as a result she fell to the ground. A neighbour, Emma Matthews, describes Laura Bonney stumbling back and slumping down the side of a car like a cartoon character. It is possible she was knocked unconscious. The two men continued fighting on the floor, the defendant telling police he got a kicking, while Laura Bonney was bleeding from the face. The defendants partner came out to prevent further trouble but he continued to shout and gesticulate. Mr Lee added how the defendant then approached the Bonneys car and kicked the car door against them, also spitting at them while the two young children sat in the vehicle. Mr Lee said: The defendant was arrested at his mothers house and told police he went out to confront the Bonneys about the abuse when Laura Bonney kicked him in the b******. He said that he then hit her without thinking but was kicked in the head by Daniel Bonney while on the ground. In an interview outside court Laura said she suffered physical pain and anxiety as a result of the attack and claims she was forced to move out of the area of St Columb Major, Cornwall, where she had been brought up not long after the fracas. Sentencing Lloyd, Judge Robert Linford said: Neighbourly disputes can become most acrimonious.  Ive got no idea what lay behind this and the truth probably lies between what the prosecution say and what you told the police. Lloyd, who pleaded guilty to affray, was made subject of an -month community order, consisting of  rehabilitation activity requirement days to address his anger problems and  hours of unpaid work. He was also ordered to pay Laura Bonney pound compensation as well as being made subject of a three-year restraining order preventing him from contacting the Bonneys, who have since separated. Speaking outside court Laura said she had suffered a lot of trauma over the incident. She said: Its been going on for a while. Initially we got on well but when I got back together with my partner things changed. Its been absolute hell. Laura said she was getting the children in the car in preparation for visiting her mother when she was attacked. She added: My son wandered off into an alleyway and I heard him shouting at my son calling him a f****** rat. He was absolutely petried. He goaded me, calling me a slag and a whore so I rushed the kids into the car then he started on me. I put my arms and legs out to try and keep him away and thats when he punched me in the face. There was blood everywhere and then he started kicking the door while my children were getting into the car. Of course they were absolutely terried.

title: pet dog plunges 100ft clifftop
story: NewsPet dog plunges from ft clftop - but miraculously walks away unharmedRNLI leboat team rescues plucky canine that accidentally fell into the sea at at Old Harry Rocks in DorsetShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  JAN NewsDinky the dog with his owner and the RNLI crew "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dog which ran off the edge of a clf and plummeted ft into the sea has miraculously survived. Staffordshire bull terrier Dinky, who was not on his lead, had wandered off as his owner chatted to another walker. Then a splash was heard – and the distraught dog lover was sure his pet had tumbled to his death. But, luckily, the tide was in and an RNLI leboat was able to rescue the plucky canine uninjured. Coastguard Kerry Jury said: “The owner only shyrealised [what had happened] when he heard a splash in the water. “Dinky was in the water for a little while before a leboat, which was nearby on training duty, recovered him. “The owner was very relieved and the dog was freezing, so it was then taken to the vet’s.”   It is believed the surface of the water broke Dinky’s fall, allowing him to paddle to a nearby beach. He was then picked up by leboat crew and wrapped in a blanket before being reunited with his relieved owner. The man in his s, who did not wish to be named, took his pet for a check-up before going home to Yeovil in Somerset. The dramatic rescue happened at chalk clfs at the Old Harry Rocks beauty spot on the Isle of Purbeck, in Dorset, on Wednesday. Becky Mack, of Swanage Leboat Station, said: “He was incredibly lucky to survive the fall in the first place and avoid hitting any rocks on the way down. “But he was then at risk of the advancing tide. “Luckily we got to him in time. By the time we reached him, the dog was out of the water but still very cold. We put him in a blanket but he seemed visibly okay.” Mr Jury added: “We would advise walkers to keep their dogs on a lead.”

story: NewsWhy Royal Family dont always wear seatbelts, according to former bodyguardSimon Morgan, of Trojan Consultancy, stressed that it was also considered on a case by case basisShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN News "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Philip made headlines when he was photographed driving while not wearing his seatbeat just days after he was involved in a horric car crash .People were outraged after the photos emerged, but according to the Royal Familys former bodyguard there might sometimes be a very good reason why members of the Firm decide against it. He claims that sometimes the royals dont buckle up as they might need to be ready to make a quick escape in an emergency.  Speaking to Hello! magazine , he said: In the threat and risk matrix its a matter of looking at each inidual situation to decide what is the best way of achieving what needs to be achieved.For example, considering that a quick entry or exit to a vehicle is easier when people arent strapped into seatbelts. He also claims that sometimes the decision is made based on the royals appearance. He said: Also, what is signicant about this event or situation  Is an iniduals look and appearance important  And also an iniduals choice.   Protection is a very unique area of policing and there are a lot grey areas, but you are always judging each situation to weigh up the risks and threats with the outcomes you are trying to achieve. Mum-of-two Emma Fairweather, who was also involved in the car crash with Prince Philip, was left with a broken arm. story: NewsopinionShow faith in UK steel - Brexit means its more vital than ever to buy BritishThe industry has been betrayed by Tory governments and now its more important than ever to buy BritishShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionThe Angel of the North sculpture by Antony Gormley"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSome of the world’s greatest structures were built with British-made steel. title: couple spot ghost monk photo
story: NewsCouple spot ghost of monk in photo from trip to haunted castleHelen Wakeman, , and John Dargan, , took a quick photo at the start of a spooky tour of Dudley Castle, West Mids, but didnt look at it properly for a few daysShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN NewsThey didnt notice the figure straight away "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A couple believe they photographed a ghost during a visit to a haunted castle.Helen Wakeman, , and John Dargan, , were flicking back through pictures from their trip to Dudley Castle, West Mids, when they spotted something strange in the background of one of the snaps. The figure, which they believe is the ghost of a former monk, is standing just metres behind them. The couple, who live in Birmingham, are keen ghost hunters and were on a haunted walk at the time but didnt spot the monk when they were there. Helen said: We were the first couple to walk up the steps so there was no one in front of us.   It was a quick memory snap and we werent expecting it to happen so early on in the tour. The tour guide told us that monks from the nearby priory would have walked up the steps towards the castle for prayers and lessons and the shape look similar to a habit. We were very freaked out. The couple didnt look at the photo straight away, but were very excited when they spotted the figure.   Helen said: We had just started the tour, on a car park close to the steps, and only took it as a quick photo, we never even looked at it till a few days later. When we finally looked through the pictures we had taken we spotted the figure next to the archway, which eerily looks like a monk with a hooded cloak. We were so excited that we had finally managed to capture something on camera.   Dudley Castle, which dates back to , is well known for its paranormal activity and has been regarded as one of the most haunted in the UK. The legend of the Grey Lady has been around for centuries, with multiple sighting of the fabled spook. According to legend the Grey Lady is the spirit of a woman called Dorothy Beaumont who died shortly after childbirth, along with her child. She wanted to buried next to her child, but her wish was never granted and so she haunts the castle grounds. Helen said: My parents bought me and John the tickets for the tour as a Christmas present as we had done a few before and got the bug for it. We have become avid ghost hunters and get a real thrill out of it but have never managed to capture anything on camera until now.

story: NewsDivers discover ,-year-old ships cargo stolen by Romans hidden in seabedThe Gallic amphoras were found in a section of water ers normally cant get to off the coast of Portofino, ItalyShareCommentsByMark Morris:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video scuba-ers-find-cargo-ancient-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo lucky scuba ers have stumbled across ancient cargo stolen by Romans and dropped in the Mediterranean Sea. The cargo, thought to be  years old, was discovered byEdoardo Sbaraini and Gabriele Succi, from Santa Margherita Ligure, Italy, in late November last year. They were surveying waters of the coast of Portofino when noticed  Gallic amphoras, or pottery, half submerged in the sand. The ers immediately informed the local Soprintendenza Archeologica , and the first ceramic jug was picked up from the ocean floor on January , .   Footage taken by the ers shows the ancient jars, of inestimable value, lying  metres under the surface. While most of them are perfectly intact, one is shattered and its remains provide shelter to all sort of sea le, including two lobsters. Edoardo said: Thanks to our underwater scooters we were able to conduct a wide survey of the waters outside of Portofino, and we found the amphoras in a place ers dont normally get to.  The first thing we noticed was the necks and flat bottoms of some of the jars popping out of the sand. When we realised what wed found we were shocked, its every ers dream to find historical relics and for us it was an incredible experience, he continued. We told the Soprintendenza about the jars and they were on the place basically on the same day.   According to Edoardo, new statements from the Department of Antiquities are expected to come out in next weeks to shed more light on the precise origin of the relics. He said: The archeologists are as excited about these findings as we are. They have said its a very unique occurrence, and they took one of the amphoras out of the water to use it as a sample and study it.

story: NewsMystery of King Tutankhamuns ,-year-old cursed tomb finally solvedKing Tutankhamuns tomb in the Valley of the Kings in Luxor, Egypt, has been restored after a -year projectShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video tutankhamun-secret-chamber-not-exist-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the mysteries of King Tutankhamuns tomb has finally been solved after the burial chamber in Egypt was painstakingly restored by experts. An international team of conservators spent  years bringing the ,-year-old, decaying tomb - once said to be cursed - back to its former glory. Over the last decade, experts stabilised wall paintings that decorate the boy-kings chamber, installed barriers and set up a ventilation system to reduce damage to the site. They also spent time investigating mysterious brown spots that were growing on wall paintings inside the tomb where the pharaohs mummied body was discovered by British Egyptologist Howard Carter in  - and it is now known what they are.   The restoration work, carried out by the US-based Getty Conservation Instituteand Egyptian Ministry of Antiquities, was unveiled on Wednesday as the tomb reopened to tourists. The brown spots were feared to be growing like a fungus, but conservators confirmed that the spots were microbes that were long dead, Live Science reported. The microbes had not spread since Carter opened the tomb almost  years ago, and they had already grown into the paint layer and could not be removed because doing so would damage the intricate artwork.  The dark spots - once thought to be caused by human interference from visitors bringing bacteria and dust into the tomb - remain on the walls. The nearly intact tomb in the Valley of the Kings in Luxor has fascinated the public - sparking mysteries and theories about a curse against those who enter it - since it was discovered by Carter. The opening of the tomb gave rise to speculation of the “pharaoh’s curse” - a myth fuelled by the death of Lord Carnarvon, who had bankrolled Carters work.  He died of blood poisoning in  after he cut himself shaving. After the discovery, Carters team removed artefacts and the site became a huge draw for tourists. Last year, researchers at Italy’s Turin Polytechnic University found no evidence that hidden chambers exist behind the tombs walls. King Tut died in about  BC at around , having reigned since he was just nine years old. The cause of the boy-kings death is disputed. Theories range from an assassination to an accidental or natural death. Zahi Hawass, Egyptologist and former minister of State for Antiquities in Egypt, said of the -year restoration: Conservation and preservation is important for the future and for this heritage and this great civilization to live forever. The tomb stayed open to tourists through much of the conservation.

story: NewsPhilippines President who compared himself to Hitler wants to jail nine-year-oldsRodrigo Duterte has sparked outrage by proposing to lower the age of criminal responsibility from  to nineShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  JAN NewsPhilippines President Rodrigo Duterte says children as young as nine should be jailed for drug offences "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA world leader who has compared himself to Hitler wants to jail nine-year-olds in his war on drugs. Groups including UNICEF and Save The Children have hit out at the plans, saying children should be protected from criminals, not punished for things they are forced to do. But activists claim the real number is far higher, with Duterte accused of turning a blind eye to extrajudicial killings. title: scientists clone five genetically altered
story: NewsScientists clone five genetically-altered baby monkeys for first timeChinese researchers have used the same technique that created Dolly the Sheep in ShareCommentsByStephen Beech:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFive cloned monkeys at a research institution in Shanghai "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Scientists have successfully cloned five genetically-altered baby monkeys for very first time.Using the same technique that produced Dolly the sheep, Chinese scientists are hailing the development as a major breakthrough. They say it will eventually mean less live monkeys having to be used in lab experiments around the world and could give fresh insight into killer diseases such as cancer.The groundbreaking quintet were born at the Institute of Neuroscienceof the Chinese Academy of Sciencesin Shanghai.Cells from a donor monkey were used to clone the five using the method of somatic cell nuclear transfer . Thats the same method that last year generated Zhong Zhong and Hua Hua, the first two cloned monkeys, and Dolly the sheep back in . Chinese scientists say the advance, reported online by the journal National Science Review, shows that a population of customised gene-edited macaque monkeys with unorm genetic background will soon be available for biomedical research.   They said the cloned quintet showed signs of a wide-range of circadian disorder characteristics - including reduced sleep time, elevated night-time locomotive activities, dampened circadian cycling of blood hormones, increased anxiety and depression, as well as schizophrenia-like behaviour. Study senior author and investigator Dr Hung-Chun Chang said: Disorder of circadian rhythm could lead to many human diseases, including sleep disorders, diabetic mellitus, cancer, and neurodegenerative diseases.  Our monkeys thus could be used to study the disease pathogenesis as well as therapeutic treatments. To create the monkey clones, Chinese researchers removed the nucleus from a monkey egg cell and replaced it with another nucleus from a fibroblast, a dferentiated somaticcell. The reconstructed egg then developed into an embryo that carries the genes of the replacement nucleus.   The embryo was then transferred to the womb of a surrogate female monkey that later gave birth to the cloned monkey. Previously, Zhong Zhong and Hua Hua were generated by using cells from an aborted fetus. The five clones were created using cells from a young adult gene-edited donor monkey. Dr Qiang Sun, director of IONs Non-human Primate Research Facility, said: Our approach is to perform gene-editing in fertilised embryos to first generate a group of gene-edited monkeys, and then select one monkey that exhibits correct gene editing and most severe disease phenotypes as the donor monkey for cloning. We believe that this approach of cloning gene-edited monkeys could be used to generate a iety of monkey models for gene-based diseases, including many brain diseases, as well as immune and metabolic disorders and cancer.   The researchers plan to continue improving the technique to increase the efficiency of cloning. They are expecting more macaque clones carrying disease-causing gene mutations to be generated in the coming years. But they said the Institute of Neuroscience follows strict international guidelines for animal research. Co-author Professor Mu-ming Poo, who directs the Institute of Neuroscience and helped to supervise the project, said: This work required coordinated efforts of many laboratories, and serves as a clear example of the efficient team work that is highly emphasised by CAS.  This line of research will help to reduce the amount of macaque monkeys currently used in biomedical research around the world. He added: Without the interference of genetic background, a much smaller number of cloned monkeys carrying disease phenotypes may be sufficient for pre-clinical tests of the efficacy of therapeutics. Since Dolly was cloned in Scotland back in , more than  species of mammals have been cloned around the world - including cattle, cats, dogs, horses and rats.

title: jim mcintyre relieved as dundee remain in scottish cup

title: no excuses from nathan ralph for dundees poor cup display
story: If excuses were his thing, full-back Nathan Ralph wouldn’t be short of a few to explain Dundee’s below-par display as they were held at home by second-tier Queen of the South in the Scottish Cup on Saturday.After the three-week winter break, the Dark Blues were not alone in looking rusty as they faced up to the Doonhamers at Dens Park.Elsewhere, as other Premiership outfits got back to competitive action for the first time since the turn of the year, the fourth round saw Motherwell crash out at home to Ross County and Aberdeen held by minnows Stenhousemuir.Dundee were also facing a team that has been in fine form of late and who, in veteran Stephen Dobbie, can boast one of the best strikers in the country, not just the Championship.That they came to Dens and turned in a high level of performance should have come as no surprise.Last, and certainly not least, what turned out to be the first leg of this tricky tie saw Dundee hand debuts to no fewer than four players in the shape of goalkeeper Seny Dieng and attackers Craig Curran, Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.With so many new faces involved, it was perhaps understandable the home team’s play at times lacked cohesion, though ironically at the weekend it was generally speaking the new players who were the pick of the bunch.That’s all the get-outs listed and Ralph isn’t too interested in any of them. For him, the bottom line is Dundee should have been better than this.“It was very frustrating on Saturday. I think our performance first half, we should be thankful we are still in the cup really,” he said.“It wasn’t good enough. They’ve got the goal to go ahead and then Jesse has done brilliantly just before half-time to get it back and have us level.“It was a good time for us to score and then we did definitely play better in the second half. On the whole, though, it was not good enough.“I suppose it does happen in the cup, we saw that with some of the other results, and the big thing is we are still in there and have a replay where we can make it into the next round.“So we maybe shouldn’t be too hard on ourselves over it but we’re still not happy with the performance.”Like most players after a bad game, now the -year-old just wants to get out on a pitch again and try to put things right.That’s why he breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday when Hearts’ televised clash with Livingston produced a result.Had the Jambos not edged past the Lions, a replay would have been tonight and Dundee’s Premiership visit to Tynecastle would have been postponed.“We have another game right away and that’s good. The one thing we didn’t want was no game this week because Hearts had drawn their cup-tie.“The thing you want to do after the winter break is get back into playing regularly again right away and you don’t want to be missing games because of things like that. You want to get points on the board as soon as possible.”Turning to the subject of the new arrivals, Ralph believes they will signicantly boost the chances of top-flight survival.So far, he’s been impressed by what he’s seen.He added: “I thought the new lads looked sharp and direct. They definitely want to get on the ball, create and make things happen.“I think them coming in this month will be good for the squad and they are going to help us going forward.”

title: one in and one out for dundee united as goalkeeper signs from hibs
story: Dundee United have signed goalkeeper Ross Laidlaw on loan from Hibs as Matej Rakovan departs the club.The Tangerines have sealed a loan deal until the end of the season for the -year-old after releasing Slovakian goalie Rakovan with  months remaining on his contract.Laidlaw has played  times for the Hibees, winning the Championship in  in the process, and will challenge with Benjamin Siegrist for the gloves at Tannadice.Manager Robbie Neilson said: “Ross joins us to compete for the first-team goalkeeping position.#He brings important experience having won this championship with Hibs and most importantly is an excellent goalkeeper.#I have been looking to improve the competition within the goalkeeping set-up, and I am happy to see Ross here.“Rakovan played  times for the Tangerines, keeping one clean sheet.

title: plans to serve dundee angus and perthshire pupils frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals
story: Tayside schoolchildren could soon be eating frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals prepared in city schools.The council is proposing to change its school meal provision from cooking on site to cooking them at a central hub and distributing them to schools.Dundee, Angus and Perth and Kinross councils are considering the proposals, with the cuisine centre in Dundee set to undergo a multi-million-pound transformationplans are approved.Dundee City Council would contribute £, towards the refurbished centre, while Tayside Contracts would be approved to borrow up to £. million from the council’s prudential loans fund to fund the work.If agreed, the move would result in the loss of  posts across the city’s schools, although it is anticipated the centralised facility would create a total of  jobs.Tayside Contracts, which handles the distribution of school meals in the region, said it would not enforce compulsory redundancies.Stuart Fairweather of Unite the Union, which represents some affected workers, said: “There will be concern among staff that any redundancies relating to the changes are not voluntary.“More broadly there will be thoughts on the implications of the changes to the service.“We want well-supported staff with the resources to provide quality meals. Any staff with concerns should contact their trade union representatives.”A report by Dundee council officials said: “We plan to change and modernise the way primary schools, early learning and childcareand community meals are delivered across Tayside.“The proposal is to provide school and community meals through a Tayside Meal Centre.“This will signicantly improve the cost-effectiveness of the community meals service.”The report acknowledges there is a risk of “signicant reduction in school meal uptake” due to a “misperception” frozen food is inferior to fresh food.The report argues that nutritional quality and standards will be easier to maintain and calls the current method of meal preparation in schools “outdated”.Tayside Contracts currently provides about . million school meals to  primary schools throughout Tayside. The meals are made in  production kitchens and transported to  schools.Children and families committee convener Stewart Hunter said: “If it is delivered effectively then the evidence from other areas where this system is used is that just as many pupils and service users take the meals as before the change.”

title: tom duthie time has come for dundee united to finally show their true title credentials
story: From the low of a shock end-of-year defeat at Alloa leading to fears the goal for the rest of the regular season would be to secure a play-off spot, things are suddenly looking up for Dundee United.The arrival in person of new owner Mark Ogren came with a pledge to give manager Robbie Neilson the funds he needs to get promotion.And perhaps, just as importantly, the promise this is a long-term project andit doesn’t happen this term, money will be ploughed in to make sure it does next. It gave everyone with a liking for the Tangerines a lt.So, too, did a dramatic shrinking of the seven-point gap at the top of the Championship courtesy of Neilson’s team taking four points from consecutive home games, while top two Ross County and Ayr United each lost two in a row.That means, for a few hours at least, United can join leaders County on the -point markthey win the second tier’s game of the weekend at Ayr on Friday night.They would, of course, still trail the Staggies, who have a vastly superior goal dference, but just being up there would be another boost.A win would also cancel out the game in hand Ayr hold over United, though they too have a better goal dference. And whatever happens at Somerset Park, Ian McCall’s team will be above themthey beat Inverness next midweek.Perhaps, though, the biggest benefit to United this weekend can be the type of performance that, whatever the points, makes a statement that they’re the ones to beat. That, unfortunately, is something they’ve largely failed to do in three seasons down in the Championship.Past glories, some of them recent, mean United start every campaign as favourites for promotion.And any team walking into Tannadice on a Saturday sees a club geared for football in the Premiership.Too often, however, any edge that’s given United has disappeared because of performances.Even when they’ve lost, in the last two-and-a-half years sides have come out of games against them feeling reputation and expectation have not matched the sum of the parts of the team they’ve faced.Results like two defeats away to Dumbarton the season before last, a - loss at Falkirk last term and two five-goal home losses in this campaign, have led to opposition throughout the ision believing they always have a chance when facing United.In truth, even the draw with Partick Thistle this month and the win over Dunfermline that closed the gap at the top to those three points, were not as convincing as was expected.That’s repeatedly been the case during the two failed attempts to get up. In the big games, too often United have come up short.They did beat Hibs at Tannadice near the end of  but lost heavily to them soon after and quickly dropped off the pace at the top.Andthey won twice at Tannadice against last season’s table toppers St Mirren, the first time came before the Buddies were regarded as their main rivals and the second after Jack Ross’s team were out of sight at the top.This time round, the best so far came up in Dingwall in November when County were beaten -.Without taking anything away from that success, after Paul Watson’s early goal put them ahead, the three points were secured via a gritty rearguard action.Yes, it was the kind of performance that is needed at times in a successful league campaign.So, too, do emphatic victories that tell the rest of the league you are a team to be feared. There would be no better time for such a statement than Friday in Ayrshire.
