title: Bid to create new whisky centre by Loch Ness
story: TALES of illicit whisky distilling on the shores of Loch Ness may feature soon in a new visitor centreplans for the facility get the go ahead from Highland Council.Hospitality and tourist operator Cobbs is teaming up with the Dingwall-based GlenWyvis Distillery to create what is being billed as the Loch Ness Whisky Experience.If approved by planners it will be sited in a redeveloped cottage by the lochside Clansman Hotel, which Cobbs owns.GlenWyvis Distillery opened in late  as the worldrsquos first  per cent community-owned, fully sustainable distillery producing single malt whisky and craft gin.It was denied permission to open its own on-site visitor centre last year amid concerns about accessibility, though it says it is still working with the council to resolve that situation.Highland Councils transport planning team are seeking more information on a number of matters related to the proposed Loch Ness development, including traffic impact and access to the A public road, but Cobbs managing director, Fraser Campbell, believes it is an exciting project with huge potential."Abriachan and the area around the Clansman Hotel was well known for illicit stills and I know the distillery has a lot of information and history which will feature at the visitor centre," he said."It is important we bring more tourists to the area and give them things to do when they are at Loch Ness."The Clansman runs fantastic boat trips, but not everyone wants to go on a boat so we want to bring other visitor experiences to the loch."We approached the distillery. They think itrsquos a great idea and we think its a great idea and of course it will be a great means of promoting their product."He added: "We get lots of bus tours from Invergordon to the hotel and this development will also help reduce traffic and help the environment because it means they will not have to spend half a day on the road travelling to a whisky experience where."GlenWyvis managing director John Mckenzie said: "This opportunity has come at the perfect time for GlenWyvis. It will give us access to a global audience and it will provide a great forum to engage with visitors who are interested in the story of whisky from a Highland community perspective. This is about the story of grass-roots distilling, distilling for the people, and, of course, that is what underpins the community ethos of GlenWyvis."The aim is to have the new visitor attraction up and running by this summer but to develop it further after that, providing both interactive and interpretative displays, as well as a retail facility.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Broken lift leaves Inverness retirement flats residents stranded
story: RESIDENTS of a retirement complex in Inverness have been left disappointed, disgusted and even frightened by a range of issues which they say goes well beyond simple teething troubles.Problems affecting the Oakwood Court development in Crown ndash which is built on the grounds of the former Inverness Royal Academy building ndash include a lt which has repeatedly broken down, leaving some elderly residents effectively stranded on the upper floors, leaking pipes and badly sealed showers which have resulted in waste water and raw sewage seeping into some flats.The car park is also poorly lit and therefore a trip hazard.Residents of the -flat site are now contemplating legal action against operator McCarthy and Stone.Residents also have concerns about the electric supply and telephone system, with telephone lines not connected or fitted in wrong flats.Resident Paul Wells said problems with the lt were the biggest issue.ldquoWe have  apartments and only one lt, which is totally unreliable, he said.The lt broke down on seven occasions between late August and the end of the year, including four days over Christmas.ldquoSome people just didnrsquot go out of their apartments because of it, it was pretty dismal, Mr Wells said.Mr Wells said there were also safety issues in the car park.ldquoWe have some very uneven surfaces and so far we have had four residents trip over at night because lighting in one part is virtually non-existent, he said.ldquoAs you can imagine, wersquore pretty fed up. We donrsquot see it as being trouble-free living at the moment. We have paid over the odds for our apartments because we were after a certain lestyle and Irsquom sure we will get it, but in the meantime, it is very frustrating and frightening for some of our residents and, in terms of the car park, quite dangerous.The residents raised their concerns in a meeting with McCarthy and Stone management , but remained unsatisfied with the response. They are now speaking to a lawyer about the possibility of legal action, Mr Wells revealed.A spokeswoman for the firm said it was very sorry to hear about the problems, but it had been working hard to resolve defects.ldquoIn line with our commitments to all of our customers, we will ensure that any such faults are rectied as quickly as possible with the minimum of inconvenience, she added, and encouraged customers to raise any concerns with staff.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Bucket loads of fun in store for Inverness
story: A CHILDRENrsquoS hospital charity is teaming up with one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic characters ndash and is on the hunt for someone to co-ordinate the Inverness end of the operation.This summer will see the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail rolled out across the country with more than  inidually decorated statues of the cheeky comic character set to grace city streets between June  and September .As well as drawing attention to the work of The Archie Foundation an auctioning off of the figures at the end of the event is also expected to raise thousands of pounds for its work in making hospital stays more pleasant for children.Around  of the statues are set to grace Inverness streets and an invitation has already been issued for creative types young or old to submit their ideas for how they should be designed.There is also a vacancy for a part-time artist co-ordinator to ensure the work is delivered by the June deadline.A spokesman for the foundation said the role would suit someone with an arts background who can co-ordinate submissions and manage artists.ldquoWe have just taken delivery of the fibre glass sculptures at a warehouse in Dundee and they will be distributed around the country in due course, he said.In terms of the designs to be applied to the statues he added: ldquoWhen we say we are looking for lsquoartistsrsquo to decorate these sculptures we are very flexible, because in Dundee we have already had one decorated by a group of children putting their handprints all over the sculpture. Sothere are community groups out there who would like to give their take on Oor Wullie we would be delighted to hear from them too.Design ideas can be submitted online until January  at www.oorwullie and applications for the co-ordinator post should be emailed to hello@archie.orgThursday  Jan  : PM

title: Chance to win a kilt and help Inverness charity
story: KILT wearers are being offered the chance to win themselves a custom-made kilt package worth pound to help an Inverness appeal.A made-to-measure kilt, tweed jacket and waistcoat are being raffled to raise money for the Haven Appeal to develop Scotlandrsquos first integrated centre for children and young people with multiple and complex needs.The raffle is being organised by Angus Beaton and Gary Smyth who teamed up to put the prize together.Both have family members with autism and also served together in the Queenrsquos Own Highlanders.Mr Beaton is a counter sales assistant at MacGregor Industrial Supplies in Henderson Road while Mr Smyth runs the family business, Scotkilt, in Harbour Road.ldquoI became aware of the Haven Appeal because my -year-old grandson, Kyle, was diagnosed with autism when he was very young, Mr Beaton said. ldquoHe would benefit from something like the Haven Centre.The pound million facility will have specialist indoor and outdoor play areas, respite flats, a community-run coffee shop and garden and offices.Mr Beaton and his colleagues at MacGregor Industrial Supplies raised pound for the appeal last year through raffles, bake sales and a tuck shop.Mr Smyth became involved in the appeal as he has a son with autism.ldquoAs like any family with this going on, it has its challenges and there needs to be more help in the Highlands for us all, he said.The jacket and waistcoat along with the kilt will be made for the winner at Scotkilt.The appeal, launched by the Elsie Normington Foundation and supported by the Inverness Courier, has raised pound. million towards the proposed Haven Centre to be built in Murray Road, Smithton.Tickets for the raffle, which will be drawn on March , cost pound each or people can donate via www.justgiving fundraising angus-beaton.Details of the project can be found on www.havenappeal.org.uk.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Demands to tear down Inverness eyesore that has lain empty for 20 years
story: FRUSTRATION is growing among community leaders over a lack of progress to tackle a long-standing eyesore within sight of Inverness Castle.B-listed Viewhill House has stood empty for more than  years and was in poor repair when it was ravaged by fire in .Since then, the roofless shell has remained a carbuncle on the city skyline, shrouded in scaffolding, overgrown bushes and weeds.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, believes it is time to consider knocking it downthere are no feasible restoration plans for the building ndash once the home of Victorian engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel.And a leading city chartered surveyor agreed, saying it was beyond economic repair.Mrs Hayden said the eyesore would ruin the view from the castle once it is turned into a visitor attraction, adding: ldquoThey are going to stand on the hill and look around them, see Viewhill and wonder what on earth it is.ldquoPersonally, I think it should be demolished. You cannot preserve something which is no longer viable. We have waited far too long for something to happen.She is due to meet Highland Council officials later this month to discuss the future of the site.Chartered surveyor Richard Smith, managing director of Allied Souter and Jaffrey, said Viewhill should come down.ldquoIt is worth absolutely nothing unless you get permission to demolish it because the renovation far outweighs its value, said Mr Smith, whose company handled the sale on behalf of the Youth Hostel Association.He also queried its listing which he claimed followed a hurried request from a council official and without a visit from the listings authority.ldquoIt was a bad listing from the point of view that it was not checked out properly, said Mr Smith, who gave a ldquostab-in-the-dark valuation of pound, for the site, based on permission for demolition and redevelopment for a residential property.At one time Viewhill was owned by building firm Ewen Gillies and later acquired by Magnus Propertieswhich is believed to be the present owner. The companyrsquos director has a correspondence address in County Antrim.Highland Council is not in active discussions with the owner and David Haas, Inverness city centre manager, said it was up to the owner to push forward any plans.ldquoAs a council, we recognise the importance of that site and will work with stakeholders who have responsibility for it to develop any opportunities, but at the moment we are not in a position to do that, he said.ldquoObviously, we are very keen to see it brought back into use.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister agreed action was now needed.ldquoI have spoken to other people who are really fed-up about it, she said. ldquoPeople think it is a disgrace.Highland Historic Buildings Trust previously pressed the case for the restoration and conversion of the property into eight-serviced apartments, but has been unable to raise the costs, estimated at pound. million in .Chairman John Duncan stressed the trust was not the owner or potential developer but got involved to try and find a solution.He said any application for demolition would have to be determined by the council and Historic Environment Scotland.In connection with another controversial Inverness building, aquestionmark hangs over when the former Eastgate Hostel will be demolished, despite previous assurances that eyesore would start to come down next week.Talks took placeon Thursdaybetween Highland Council and representatives acting for the owners of the building which has remained a fire-ravaged eyesore for  days now.Afterwards, neither party would confirm whether work would begin next week, although they insisted the meeting was ldquovery positive.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose business is nearby, called for the council to take out a compulsory purchase orderwork does not start by next Friday.ldquoThere has been no sign of activity so far, he said.ldquoIt is an absolute nonsense.Building consultant Gary Johnston, agent for the owners Imtaiz Ali and Mr Cheng, would not confirm when work would begin. All he could say was: ldquoEverything is going according to plan.David Haas, Highland Councilrsquos Inverness city manager, said matters were progressing in a constructive way.ldquoIt is very frustrating it has taken so many years to get to this stage but the principal owner has taken major steps in the last six months, he insisted.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Drive on to extend free parking in Inverness city centre
story: CITY businesses are pushing for an extension to free parking in the centre of Inverness as a year-long trial they have hailed as a success comes to an end.Backed by the Inverness Courier, Inverness Business Improvement Districtpersuaded Highland Council to introduce a system of free  minutes of on-street parking last year across a broad swathe of the city centre.Parking meters were converted to provide free tickets for  on-street spaces, after research suggested similar schemes have had a positive impact on footfall in other urban centres such as Perth.The trial period is now coming to an end and business figures, who argue it has been a hit, are hoping it will be extended ndash both in terms of the amount of time shoppers will be able to enjoy free parking for and the number of sites they can us.Local butcher Duncan Fraser who has premises in Queensgate said: ldquoThe businesses I have spoken to would like to see it extended to half an hour.ldquoFteen minutes is fine, but a bit tightyou have to go to a couple of shops or get caught up in the post office.ldquoWe certainly would not like to see this withdrawn.And David Miele, who runs the hugely successful Mielersquos Gelateria in Church Street, is also hoping councillors will look at making better use of the parking space available.ldquoThere are too many loading bays which lie empty for most of the day, he said.ldquoWhen wardens pass our premises customers basically get up and go out because they fear getting a ticket.ldquoI welcome the free parking and would like to see it increased.They are being backed in their calls by Inverness Central councillor and depute provost Bet McAllisterldquoIt has clearly been welcomed by the traders and enables people to get in to the town centre and attend to business, but you canrsquot do a lot in  minutes, she said.ldquoI would rather see it extended to half an hour so people can pop into a couple of shops, go to the library or even stop for a coffee.And she added: ldquoMany older people would benefit greatly from a longer stay.ldquoWe have to look at the bigger picture. The Victorian Market is generally used by older people and it needs more customers. Longer-stay free parking would help.BID manager Mike Smith said it believes the free parking has been beneficial.ldquoInverness BID subscribes to the view that parking is all part of the city centre marketing offer to the public, he said.ldquoWe appreciate the financial pressures Highland Council is under, but we should not lose sight of that mantra.Shane Manning, principal officer for traffic and planning at Highland Council, confirmed councillors are set to evaluate the schemersquos impact when the Inverness city area committee meets on February . They will decide at that point whether to continue with it.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Funding could lead to new life for Inverness park
story: A BOLD vision to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildings could take a step forward later this month.Campaigners are exploring the possibility of transferring ownership of the Northern Meeting Park in Ardross Street to a community-run group in a bid to enable greater access to the venue.The Northern Meeting Park Group is now waiting to hear whether a funding application has been successful for a feasibility study to prepare a five-year business plan plus architectural reports and surveys.If all goes according to plan, the study could begin before the end of January while the long-awaited project could be achieved by the end of next year.The group is also looking for two trustees from the local community ndash taking in the neighbourhoods of Park, Balleary and Dalneigh and Columba ndash to join its -strong board.Chairman Jon Ford expects this year to be a busy one in trying to push forward the proposals for the -year-old park whose gates are usually kept locked.The group has applied for a grant from the Scottish Land Fund with advice from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and hopes to get match funding from the Architectural Heritage Fund.In total, the initial studies are expected to cost pound,.ldquoWe know there are a lot of other people out there also looking for funding but we are very optimistic, he said.ldquoThat would be the first stage. The next stage would be to apply for funding to acquire the Northern Meeting Park and have it transferred into community ownership.Highland Council would also have to agree to transfer ownership of the park.Mr Ford acknowledged there had been some resistance from a few councillors including those who had mistakenly thought the idea was to turn the park into a private business venture.ldquoNone of us likes change, he said. ldquoI can understand it on one level but not on another when you are talking about a publicly-owned asset which is kept locked up and not used especially as it is four acres of grass in the city centre which could be used for recreation.ldquoI cannot understand why people are resistant to that notion. In our view this is a way for Highland Council to think outside the box.Hundreds of people accessed the park during a two-week trial last summer when the gates were opened each day between am and pm.Mr Ford hopes a similar trial will be carried out around Easter.Anyone interested in becoming a trustee can contact the group via www.northernmeetingpark, or call  .Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Go ahead for River Ness hydro scheme
story: A SPECTACULAR hydro electric scheme close to the heart of Inverness has been given the green light by Highland Council, and it is hoped it will not only be a source of power, but also an attractive feature on the River Ness.Council officials granted the application for the lsquoArchimedes screwrsquo to be built into the bank next to Holm Mills Bridge near the West Link distributor road but have placed a total of  conditions on the project to safeguard visual amenity, road and pedestrian safety.The project has been warmly welcomed with local councillor Alex Graham, he said: ldquoThis project was first mooted about three years ago and then it came back towards the end of last year. Historically hydro power was generated there in the s in the building that is now the ice-cream shop.ldquoIn the present climate I think it is a very welcome project, one that can not only generate power locally but also become a feature to be enjoyed by visitors and locals.Helen Smith, who is on Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot comment on it but it is tucked away quite far from residential buildings. But from my point of view, personally its fine, I remember there was hydro power there in the past and it might be quite attractive. Irsquod be surpriseit bothers any local residents.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. title: Inverness schoolgirl coining it in thanks to generous donation
story: AN Inverness schoolgirlrsquos coin collecting hobby has received a boost after she was given a bag of assorted coins by a well-wisher.The man, who insisted on remaining anonymous, came to the Inverness Courier office with the money after we ran a story about Isla MacDonald becoming online coin club Change Checkerrsquos award-winning junior member of .Islarsquos interest in specially minted coins was sparked by the finding of a Girl Guides centenary p and now the Cradlehall Primary pupil has  special p coins and  dferently designed pound coins.Her father Simon helped her to research the first coin and she began keeping an eye out for other coins which are unusual and collectable.Her mother Luisa said: ldquoIt is a shame this man has asked to remain anonymous because we would love to write a thank you letter to him. It was really kind of him. Isla is delighted and fascinated by the selection of coins that was in the bag.Islarsquos coin collection includes several rare items, including coins marking the Commonwealth Games in England, London Underground and Paddington Bear.Like her fellow collectors, she is keeping a sharp eye out for Kew Gardens which remains the most scarce p coin currently in circulation.Among the gted coins is a  pound coin issued to mark  years since the Declaration of Rights being enacted which effectively shted the balance of power from the Crown to parliament and changed the course of British political history.Another is a pound coin which was minted in  to mark the centenary of Entente Cordiale, agreements made between the UK and French governments.Two Cornish halfpennies, and a pound and p from the Isle of Man are also included, as well as a square coin marking the bicentenary of the Battle of Jersey.Although not a coin, the bag included a highly nostalgic ldquoOfficial Licensed Medallion marking that Scotland had qualied for the  World Cup in France. Five World Cups have come and gone since without Scotland managing to qualy.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Loss of Inverness nightclub is sad for the city
story: THE closure of Club Tropicana brings to an end  yearsrsquo experience of working in Inverness nightclubs for Roy Dunnett.However, Mr Dunnett believes the closure is not just sad news for himself and the  colleagues who have been made redundant, but for Inverness as a whole.ldquoInverness used to have three big nightclubs, but now we have city status and a growing student population with the UHI and Inverness doesnrsquot have any, Mr Dunnett said. ldquoThere are plenty of drinking places in Inverness, but we lack a physical nightclub. A lot of stag and hen parties come up to Inverness now and they want to go to a club to finish their night, which they would do back home. They donrsquot want to be in a bar that serves food.Mr Dunnett also worked at Grsquos nightclub on Castle Street, which Club Tropicana owner TGC Leisure closed in May . story: Positivity from staff at an Aberdeen out-of-school club leaves children feeling respected and nurtured, inspectors said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited the club at Stoneywood School on Greenburn Road, Bucksburn, on December  and have now published their report.The club provides care for up to  children of school age.Inspectors rated it “good” for care, support, staffing, environment, management and leadership – the third best of six possible ratings.“Interactions between children and staff were positive so children felt respected and nurtured,” the report said.It added: “Staff had a good knowledge of children’s needs and were able to clearly outline how they were meeting these.“The dining hall was used for the club and this provided plentul space for the children to play.“We found the quality of care to be good.”

title: childrens charity in plea for more volunteers
story: A Childline volunteer in the north-east has called for more people to join the charity.Linda Stephen was recently awarded a British Empire Medal for her nine years voluntary work with the organisation.The -year-old has called on more people to get involved with the Aberdeen base to help children who might be dealing with a range of problems including bullying, self-harm and suicide.She said: “Receiving the award was very unexpected and is quite humbling. title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

And an aerial appliance was also mobilised by Scottish Fire and Rescue service. Firefighters battled the flames well into the night . The road remained closed after pm, eyewitnesses said. title: new south ayrshire headteacher bagged
story: NewsNew South Ayrshire headteacher has bagged dream jobGaenor Hardy,, has assumed control at Heathfield in Ayr, complete with its  pupil roll and  child nursery.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsGaenor Hardy "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe new boss of South Ayrshire’s biggest primary school has bagged her “dream job”. Gaenor Hardy,, has assumed control at Heathfield in Ayr, complete with its  pupil roll and  child nursery. And the shining star of the region’s education system confesses she is now “living in a bubble waiting for it to burst”. Gaenor, who joins Heathfield after heading up Dalmilling Primary for five years, said: “I was very happy there and only Heathfield would have pulled me away. “It is always the school I have aspired to. My twins came here and I feel that level of affinity. “All I see is potential. I’ve never been at a school where the surroundings in the community are so rich.” Gaenor cut her teaching teeth in south London before ing north after her sister suffered a severe stroke, aged just . She said: “It made me review my le and decide what was important so we relocated back up to Scotland. “I’ve been back here for  years now and always had one eye on Heathfield as I knew it was such an exciting job. “Part of that excitement is that I live in the catchment and my children went here so it feels like coming home. “But I’m also excited about making this the flagship school. “However, we also need to make this the hub of the local community.” Fitness fanatic Gaenor admits an “open and frank exchange of views” took place during the first meeting with her new parent council last week. It follows concerns over the previous management’s approach to alleged bullying within the school. But she insisted: “I’m all for honest, vibrant and lively dialogue. “None of it was a surprise to me as a parent myself. “I would hate to think I’ll be a comparison to previous management in the school. “What I can bring is my own unique experience to the role. “I want to be open and visible and have parents approach me. “This has to be us together on the journey.” And she added: “I don’t have to grow a passion for the school. It is there within me already. “I feel like I’m in a bubble of looking forward to coming to work and being so motivated – and I’m still waiting for it to be burst.” Now Gaenor, who is often seen walking to school, is planning to get her pupils into shape as part of a new physical and mental drive. She said: “If I want the children to be fit and healthy then I have to model that. “Health and wellbeing has to underpin everything we’re doing. “The local junor parkrun is an example of something I’d like to see encouraged. “We’ve also rolled out more than  after-school and lunch clubs from this month. “I’ll be doing a homework club and the clerical team are doing a running club so we’re all very hands on. “But ultimately the children are my inspiration. “We have a fantastic new building in which to work and I’ve never experienced anything like it during my career. “Now the challenge is to make the most of it and enjoy what we have.”

title: new super school riddled structural
story: NewsNew super-school is riddled with structural problemsLeaks, faulty automatic doors and sensory lights are among a string of issues at Invergarven’s marquee campus in Girvan.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsInside the school "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new pound million super-school is “riddled” with structural problems, it can been revealed. Leaks, faulty automatic doors and sensory lights are among a string of issues at Invergarven’s marquee campus in Girvan. The school’s swimming pool has also not been used since the ribbon was cut back in August. Council chiefs, who hailed the building as a huge boost for education, admit they have hit “snagging issues”. One senior source said: “The place was leaking like a sieve. “You expect the odd snag with any new building but this is far more than that. “It seems like the pressure was on to move in on time and clearly things haven’t been ready. “To be fair the place has been riddled with problems since day one.” The Post understands that a squad of up eight workers have been sent in to fix ongoing problems. And staff have still to be trained in using the hydrotherapy pool some five months after the school’s opening. Girvan councillor, Iain Fitzsimmons, said: “The school is going to be a great facility for this area. “The staff are also incredibly hard working and deserve a lot of praise. “I am assured that a number of snagging issues are in the process of being fixed and in the pool will be in use by February.” A council spokesman added: “Since the school opened we’ve received very positive feedback from staff, children, parents and the community on a fantastic new facility that’s helping to transform education for children and young people. “The hydrotherapy pool is in full working order and staff are currently being trained to make the best use of this central new feature. “Our contract also provides for snagging issues to be dealt with as and when required.”
